Key Arguments: The Bill undermines freedom of expression and is paternalistic.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation are vague and open to abuse.
The Bill assumes that government and tech platforms can better discern truth than the public.
Historical examples show that governments and corporations have been major sources of misinformation.
The Bill contradicts scientific and philosophical reasoning by promoting consensus over individual discovery.
The Bill poses a threat to fundamental human freedoms and the pursuit of truth.
Notable Quotes: The proposed 2023 Communications Legislation Amendment, Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation, henceforth ‘the Bill’, represents at best a dangerously ill-conceived, presumptuous and paternalistic attempt to undermine Australians’ freedom of expression.
The Bill can thus be thought of as a legal enshrinement of fascism in Australia.
The anti-scientific strictures of the Bill lay the foundations, at best, for apathy and stagnation.
I strongly urge the rejection of this most dangerous of legislative impositions on the fundamental rights and freedoms of Australians.
